titles.title: Lincoln Highway Study Act of 1999
Lincoln Highway Study Act of 2000

To require the Secretary of the Interior to undertake a study regarding methods to commemorate the national significance of the United States roadways that comprise the Lincoln Highway, and for other purposes.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on Resources.
Referred to the Subcommittee on National Parks and Public Lands.
Referred to Department of the Interior for comments.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported by Unanimous Consent.

action.text: Reported by the Committee on Resources. H. Rept. 106-912.

calendar.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 547.

action.text: Mr. Calvert moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 2570.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate, read twice.

vote.text: Passed Senate without amendment by Unanimous Consent.

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.

bill.summary: 7/20/1999--Introduced. Lincoln Highway Study Act of 1999 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service, to coordinate a comprehensive study of routes comprising the Lincoln Highway. Requires that such study: (1) include an evaluation of its significance in American history, options for the preservation and use of remaining segments of the highway, and options for the preservation and interpretation of significant features association with such highway; and (2) consider private sector preservation alternatives. Directs that the study provide for the participation of representatives from each State traversed by such highway, State historic preservation offices, representatives of associations interested in its preservation, and persons knowledgeable in American history, historic preservation, and popular culture. Sets forth reporting requirements. Authorizes appropriations.
